title: Can an individual change the course of history? - Quora

In conclusion, people who have great vision, confidence, proper curiosity, potentiality of working hard and desire to change the society can only change the course of history. A person needs to give everything and should never give up which common person can’t do. Common People don’t have that power to change the course of history.

Literally, the individuals that have changed history have either been Empire-builders, religious leaders or scientists. When a culture is conquered, existing historical writing is destroyed or altered to reflect the new Empire in a favorable light. All of our existing historical literature has been rewritten many, many times. When the religious awakening of an individual is sufficiently different from the dogma of its times, that attracts followers. Followers mean growth and recognition which leads to more followers, hierarchy and institutional power. That power can affect cultural change on a very wide scale. Finally, sometimes, a scientist or inventor, working initially at least, alone and unfunded, can through perseverance discover unique new properties leading to new tools or to objects or medicines that improve people’s lives. Those individuals affect the unfolding of history as more and more people become aware of the discovery and make us of things that evolve from it. Some will say that artists including fine artists, writers and musicians can change history’s course, but to me these all serve mostly to reflect the existing culture and human condition. Even in aspiration, creative arts usually inspire more individual reflection and thought about what is and might be. That is different than the broad-scale, immediate affects of conquest, religion or science.

Without Jesus and Paul, the Roman empire would have simply evaporated. Thanks to Christian monks portions of the Classical civilization survived to instruct the Celto-Germanic remnants of Rome. Julius Ceaser affected both Gaul and the Eastern Mediterranean in major ways. Without Gaul, there would not be a land Roman empire nor a clash with the Germans. Without Egypt, Rome would be commercially dependent upon the East- vastly changing the imperial dynamics. Charlemagne changed the political dynamics of continental Europe. William made England a continental power and imposed ‘modern’ government on the Anglo-Saxons. William of Orange changed the dynamics of Western Europe. He consolidated the ‘constitutional’ monarchy of Britain and brought the enormous power of Britain into the modern era. No other leader could have reconciled the British Whigs and the Tories. George Washington refused to become ‘an elective monarch’ by declining the third term. Only Lincoln could have held the Union together AND won the Civil War. William II Hohenzollern transformed a blossoming Europe into a charnel house by letting the von Schlieffen plan go forward without comment. Hitler ignited WW II all by himself. Individuals do make a difference.

History cannot be “changed”. It is written, forever. History is not some guy leading an army against all odds and winning. Likely, there were already factors working in his favor hundreds, or sometimes thousands of years in the making. The only occasion other I can think of off the top of my head is the rise of Hitler. After the Treaty of Versailles and the Russian Revolution, Germany was destined to be communist. Instead of the Iron Curtain being on the Rhine, it was much further east. Or Stalin killing Trotsky, who was destined in leading a global communist revolution, possibly leading to World War Three. I am writing a book on how these individuals obtain power. In a world of 7 billion, one Hitler or one Stalin is not very odd. It is the people.

Absolutely. One of the great hinges of history occurred on September 26th, 1983, when Soviet early warning systems reported a launch of five American middles directed at the Soviet Union. The officer on duty that day, Stanislav Petrov, made a judgment call that the report must be a false alarm and did not report the alert. Petrov is arguably responsible for single handedly avoiding a probable massive Soviet retaliation that would have resulted in Global Thermonuclear War.  Russian RT-2PM2 Topol-MIntercontinental ballistic missile - Wikipedia It is impossible for me to think, in light of this simple, yet globally crucial event, that anything subsequent in human history is not potentially subject to change by one individual.

Despite the way this question is worded, it’s obvious you mean to change the course of things, the direction they’re taking, and make the path turn a different way from the one it currently seems to be going. One way is to create a work of art that touches many hearts and inspires people to write about it and talk about it, not just something that will only appeal to your chronological contemporaries, but something that will be a classic and inspire the pondering of options and behavior. You could always make an important discovery or invent something helpful as well. Also, by being kind to everyone you come across, you’re changing many things for the better but just don’t see the good results of actions that cost you nothing… a kind word here and there can make a world of difference to someone, and that person may affect the future’s course. There are many other ways to achieve this as well.

How can people change the course of history? They can go out and be activists, campaign for a cause, demonstrate for their beliefs. Common people can be part of something larger than themselves and change the course of history. Take the Arab Spring for instance: the people demonstrated against their governments and the conflicts directly resulting from this had far-reaching consequences.  Tunisia had its government overthrown; Egypt and Yemen had their governments overthrown multiple times; Jordan, Palestine, Oman, Kuwait, and Morocco all saw changes made to government; Syria and Libya fell into civil war; Algeria, Sudan, Lebanon, and Iraq saw major protests; and Saudi Arabia, Somalia, and Mauritania had minor protests. The protesters were undoubtedly “common,” yet they had massive geopolitical influence that we are still feeling today. They certainly changed the course of history.

Imagine how different the aftermath of the American Civil War could've been if John Wilkes Booth hadn't assassinated Abraham Lincoln. Would the English language be completely changed if Shakespeare had never put pen to paper? And then there's the big one. What would've happened if Hitler was never born or had died in the trenches of World War I? Would we have avoided the most devastating conflict in human history or would another “Hitler” have risen to take his place? Though we'll never get a real answer to these questions, there's certainly works of alternate history that cover thenones I mentioned and many more.

In many ways, by being an activist and promoting a cause or by being a general and leading forces to victory or defeat. One can even change history by committing an act of terror.
